body: We have serialization and round-tripping tests.
What I mean is my understanding is that we do not have any logic to serialize known types (so this new deserialization code is not exercised). I'm happy to be wrong though.
Ah, yes, the serialization logic is only available in Python.

Coverage remained the same at 70.702% when pulling **c74b6083264cb04e047f2ac05b374c0b07be4fdc on robertwb:gen-proto** into **36436768dba354ffbc68df0b3761a447c6814dfb on apache:master**.

This PR seems to greatly slow down `mvn clean compile` because now instead of just compiling Java code, this also installs some python packages and compiles a ton of C code.

Can still be worked around by adding `-pl '!sdks/python'`, which brings time for `mvn clean compile test-compile` from 5:30 minutes to 1:30.

Yes, it is a pity we didn't discuss this particular PR at Apachecon, I will redo the PR once I can but remember this is part 1 of 2, the second part is where I expect some debate. I will ping you back once I check this again.
LGTM, thanks.

On most machines pre-compiled wheels should be available to avoid compiling
all the C code. (This is, in fact, why I'm avoiding setup_requires...) What
system are you using?

Even faster is simply installing grcpio_tools into your Python (it checks
to see if it's available before fetching it.)

Jenkins tests are failing with `ImportError: No module named value_provider`
Agree, I have some ideas as well (we can chat on Slack). I'm merging.
Rebase it.

@jkff my idea is to mimic the runner calling `start()` and `advance()` on the reader by hand (as the runner does). Than, before the last message, I can:
- get the checkpoint and create a new reader with this checkpoint to verify that it resumes correctly
- check that the messages are actually acknowledged when we do `finalizeCheckpoint()`

Does it sounds reasonable to you ?
retest this please
I have seen this failure (or something like it) in Spark on other PRs, totally unrelated. So I wouldn't necessarily block on it, but we should see what is going on there.

I think you could make a case that `ReadableState#read()` should be `@Nullable` but I don't quite like it.

My perspective is more that `ReadableState<T>#read()` does not return a `@Nullable T` but rather `ValueState<T>` really implements `ReadableState<@Nullable T>` because the other types of state don't need to return `null`.
(the change in this PR is an example of just what I mean)
